abstract: Dr Kaveh Pahlevan and Dr Alessandro Morbidelli study in journal Nature posits mini-planets passing close to moon soon after its formation tipped its orbit out of plane of other planets; study also suggests similar bodies slamming into earth are responsible for precious metals in Earth's crust.
lead_paragraph: Two planetary scientists believe that large objects passed the moon repeatedly over tens of millions of years and tipped its orbit, some hitting Earth and leaving precious metals behind.

headline.main: Scientists Link Moon’s Tilt and Earth’s Gold
headline.print_headline: Scientists Link the Moon’s Tilt to Precious Metals on Earth

snippet: Two planetary scientists believe that large objects passed the moon repeatedly over tens of millions of years and tipped its orbit, some hitting Earth and leaving precious metals behind.
